Description: Attic pottery squat lekythos; the mouth and most of handle are missing, some chips around the foot; surface slightly eroded. Body covered in net pattern with added white dots.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Town (Naukratis), House of 'cache of bronzes' (possibly)
Curator's comments: 1885.1101.65 and 1930.0901.1 in black ink on underside. 103 on bottom in pencil. 22234 black in base of neck. 26 black ink on neck.

This fragmentary lekythos might come from a large cache of bronze votives discovered in 1885 in a house to the south of the town (Petrie 1886, 41-42). Petrie mentioned among the finds a ‘small brown vase with black net pattern of cross lines, and white spots at the crossings’. Other net-patterned lekythoi from Attica were found inNaukratis. This example however was acquired in 1885 and is kept in the British Museum, as are all non-bronze finds identified as belonging to the cache (Masson 2015). The cache can be dated around the end of the 5th-beginning of the 4th century BC. Petrie, W. M. F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I., 1884-5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Masson, A. 2015, ‘Cult and Trade. A reflexion on Egyptian metal offerings from Naukratis’, in D. Robinson and F. Goddio (eds), Thonis Heracleion in Context, Oxford Centre for Maritime Archaeology Monograph 8, Oxford, 71-88.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.1965)
Masson 2015 / Cult and Trade A reflexion on Egyptian metal offerings from Naukratis (73, fig. 3.2)
